channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Parisian Pools, Up Close and Personal
item.description: Swimming in Paris is a full-on cultural experience, offering intimate views into the French psyche, which is on near-naked display in the swimming lanes, locker rooms and (mostly coed) showers.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: People swimming beneath the vaulted ceiling of the Butte-aux-Cailles municipal pool last month in Paris.

item.title: Turkey’s Women’s Volleyball Team Inspires Pride
item.description: Turkey is basking in the success of players it calls “Sultans of the Net,” seeing paragons of female empowerment in a country grappling with multiple crises.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fans in Istanbul celebrate as Turkey’s national women’s volleyball team beat Italy in the Women’s European Volleyball Championship.

item.title: How the Khakova Dam Disaster Continues to Devastate Ukraine
item.description: Environmentally, economically and in terms of pure human suffering, the destruction of the Kakhovka dam unleashed untold damage. Months later, many communities are still reeling.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: In Italy, Rape Cases Seize Attention and Expose Cultural Rifts
item.description: A summer of horrific crimes, including the gang rapes of two young girls, has put a new focus on the country’s attitudes toward women and the amplifying role of social media.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned swimming pool that the police say was one place where two young girls were raped by a gang of their peers, all residents of the town of Caivano, on the outskirts of Naples.

item.title: Saudi Dissident’s Brother Is Sentenced to Death for Social Media Posts on Royals
item.description: Under a crackdown on dissent by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, prosecutors accused a retired teacher of treason after he criticized the ruling family.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim

item.title: China to Its People: Spies Are Everywhere, Help Us Catch Them
item.description: As Beijing tries to enlist the “whole of society” to guard against foreign enemies, the line between vigilance and paranoia fades.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: Surveillance cameras in Shanghai in March.

item.title: Crisis-Hit British Museum Names Interim Director
item.description: Mark Jones, a former leader of the Victoria and Albert Museum, is set to take over with a remit to restore confidence after a theft scandal.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British Museum is the world’s third most visited, after the Louvre and the Vatican Museums.

item.title: Russia Attacks Ukrainian River Port, Injuring at Least 2
item.description: The assault in the Odesa region came as Ukraine’s president said two more ships had traveled through a temporary corridor established by Kyiv after Moscow pulled out of the Black Sea grain deal.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A cargo ship on the Danube near the Ukrainian river port of Izmail last month. Shipping via the Danube River has become crucial since Russia pulled out of a deal allowing grain transport on the Black Sea.

item.title: Officials Knew of Problems at Building That Caught Fire in South Africa
item.description: An extensive paper trail reveals that the authorities in Johannesburg were warned repeatedly about the dangers in the derelict building where 76 people died in a fire this week.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Lynsey Chutel and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: The scene of the fire in Johannesburg on Friday.

item.title: A Nation With Few Catholics Gives Pope a Welcome Fit for an Emperor
item.description: Mongolia put its history and culture on display as Pope Francis visited the Asian nation. Although it was the first trip to the country by a Roman Catholic pontiff, he noted that the two entities have ties dating back many centuries.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis with Mongolia’s president in front of a giant Genghis Khan statue on Saturday at a welcome ceremony in Ulaanbaatar.

item.title: New Evidence in 2014 Mass Kidnapping of Students in Iguala, Mexico
item.description: The Mexican police, military officers and others secretly colluded with a cartel that kidnapped 43 students, a case unsolved after nearly a decade. Wiretaps show just how much the authorities helped the cartel behind the mass abduction, and what led to it.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters in Mexico City of some of the 43 students who were kidnapped in 2014 by the police and turned over to a cartel.

item.title: Democracy in Bangladesh Is Quietly Being Crushed
item.description: The most active rivals to the country’s ruling party face dozens, even hundreds, of court cases each, paralyzing the opposition as a crucial election approaches.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
item.media:description: A rare rally by the political opposition in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in July. A few weeks later, the police crushed another opposition rally.

item.title: A Crackdown on Free Speech in Jordan
item.description: A satirical Arabic website, much like The Onion, poked fun at a royal wedding in Jordan in June. Not long after, it was blocked. “We’re totally backsliding,” said one cartoonist in the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Parliament members at a session on the cybercrime law in July in Jordan’s capital, Amman.

item.title: South African Inquiry Rebuts U.S. Charge on Russian Arms
item.description: A government investigation about a Russian ship contradicts U.S. accusations that South Africa provided arms to fight Ukraine, President Cyril Ramaphosa said. But a government report won’t be released, he added.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The Lady R cargo ship docked in December at Simon’s Town Naval Base in South Africa.

item.title: Netanyahu Calls for Deportations of Immigrants After Clashes in Tel Aviv
item.description: The Israeli prime minister’s remarks revived a debate about the fate of thousands of asylum seekers after hundreds of opposing Eritrean groups faced off in Tel Aviv this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Rival groups of Eritreans threw stones at each other and police officers in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Three American Lives Forever Changed by a Weapon Now Being Sent to Ukraine
item.description: The mother of a Marine and two veterans who served in Iraq reflect on the U.S. decision to send failure-prone shells to help the Ukrainian military battle Russia.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lance Cpl. Travis J. Bradach-Nall was killed while clearing an area of cluster weapons.

item.title: Nobel Foundation Withdraws Invitation to Russia and Belarus
item.description: The foundation, which also excluded both countries last year because of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, retracted an invite after the move drew outrage.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: The Nobel Prize award ceremony in Stockholm last year.

item.title: Russia Says It Thwarted Another Attack on the Kerch Strait Bridge
item.description: Russia’s Ministry of Defense said it had destroyed three sea drones targeting the Kerch Strait Bridge, a vital supply line for Moscow’s forces that links occupied Crimea to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The Kerch Strait Bridge in July.

item.title: Cross-Cultural Exchanges from Vietnam, Ethiopia, the Caribbean
item.description: Solo shows also abound, from Charles Gaines to Harry Smith, while the women of Land Art and Fluxus keep rocking in major exhibitions.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter

item.title: India Launches Its First Solar Mission
item.description: The goal is to study the sun’s outer layers, to better understand its physics and dynamics and to improve understanding of space weather.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: R. Satish Babu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People watching as a rocket carrying the Aditya L1 spacecraft, India’s first space-based observatory to study the sun, is launched on Saturday.

item.title: Europe’s Boars Still Hold Radioactivity. What Surprised Scientists Is Why.
item.description: Some wild boar hunted in German forests have radiation levels that exceed the limit deemed safe for human consumption. New research suggests that it’s not just because of Chernobyl.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Martin Zwick/Reda&Co/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A wild boar in the Bavarian Forest National Park in southern Germany.

item.title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Pushes Forward, Village by Village
item.description: As Ukraine pushes slowly forward in its counteroffensive, it’s relying heavily on the effort of hundreds of small-scale assault groups, each tasked with attacking a single trench, tree line or house.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: Ukrainian Army soldiers fire a self-propelled howitzer at targets in the direction of Bahkmut city on the eastern frontline, on Monday.

item.title: Plea Deal May Be Near for a Bali Bombing Defendant at Guantánamo
item.description: The case of a Guantánamo detainee charged by a military commission over terrorist attacks in Indonesia two decades ago is no longer joined to that of two other defendants.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Carol Rosenberg

item.title: Bill Pinkney, Globe-Circling Sailor Who Set a Racial Mark, Dies at 87
item.description: He was the first Black person to sail alone by way of the arduous southern route, rounding the perilous Cape Horn and withstanding storms and loneliness.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Bill Pinkney in Chicago aboard his 47-foot cutter, Commitment, in September 1989. He set sail on his epic voyage the following August out of Boston.

item.title: U.S. Knew About Migrant Killings by Saudi Forces Earlier Than Previously Disclosed
item.description: The State Department says diplomats in Riyadh learned of the atrocities from research groups last summer, contradicting an earlier statement that the United States was not aware until December.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ethiopian migrants in the eastern Yemen province of Amran walked toward the Saudi border last month.

item.title: No Charges Filed Over Death of Adama Traoré in France
item.description: Adama Traoré, 24, died in 2016 shortly after three officers pinned him to the ground during an arrest. His case became a symbol for activists protesting police violence in France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A portrait of Adama Traoré in Persan, France, during demonstrations in 2020 to commemorate the fourth anniversary of his death.

item.title: Body Is Found in Search for Missing British Poet
item.description: The police said they had found a man’s body after a search for Gboyega Odubanjo, 27, who was last seen on Saturday at a music festival in England where he was set to perform.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Hezbollah Sanctions Case Highlights Frailties in the Art Market
item.description: In its indictment of a collector accused of helping the militant group, U.S. prosecutors presented evidence of how easily art sales can be used to evade sanctions and launder money.
item.dc:creator: Julia Halperin and Graham Bowley

item.title: As Anniversary of Women’s Uprising Nears, Iran Cracks Down
item.description: Sept. 16 marks one year since Mahsa Amini died in the custody of the morality police, setting off months of protests. Authorities are trying to quell any new unrest.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A police motorcycle burned during a protest after Mahsa Amini died in police custody last year in Tehran. Iranian intelligence agents were monitoring any activity related to dissent ahead of the first anniversary of her death.

item.title: What I’m Reading: Buried Secrets
item.description: In countries that have emerged from brutal 20th-century dictatorships, the past isn’t staying in the past.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Pictures of those believed to have been disappeared in Chile under the military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet were projected onto the Palacio de la Moneda in Santiago, Chile, on Wednesday.

item.title: Paris Becomes the First European Capital to Ban Rented Electric Scooters
item.description: But the city is adding bike lanes, and scooter companies are shifting their focus to electric bikes. E-scooters were involved in accidents resulting in the deaths of three people in Paris last year.
item.dc:creator: Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
item.media:description: A worker loading an electric scooter into a van in Paris last month. A ban on the scooters began in the city on Friday.

item.title: French Citizen Killed After Straying Into Algerian Waters
item.description: The man was one of several French-Moroccan dual citizens vacationing in northern Morocco when their water scooters, low on fuel, drifted across the maritime border and the coast guard opened fire.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Aida Alami
item.media:description: Relatives carried the body of Bilal Kissi at his funeral on Thursday in Saidia, Morocco. He was shot dead by the Algerian coast guard after his motorized water scooter strayed into Algerian waters.

item.title: Filthy Toilets, No Showers and Criminal Landlords: Life in a South African Firetrap
item.description: After harrowing escapes from the apartment fire in Johannesburg that killed at least 74 people, residents described how they managed to build lives with no legal water or electricity, and very little privacy.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Tom Mandala, center, wearing a cast on Friday. He escaped a burning building by jumping from an upper-floor window.

item.title: Tropical Storm Idalia Turning Away From Bermuda
item.description: Tropical storm warnings for Bermuda, which had been issued earlier on Saturday, have been discontinued, forecasters said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford
item.media:description: Idalia, now a post-tropical cyclone, off the Atlantic Coast of the United States on Friday. It was moving away from Bermuda on Saturday.

item.title: Thai King Commutes Sentence of Former Prime Minister Thaksin
item.description: Thaksin Shinawatra’s eight-year punishment was reduced to one year, days after his return from self-imposed exile. He remains one of the country’s most influential politicians.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Thaksin Shinawatra, center, the former Thai prime minister, and his daughters Pintongta Kunakornwong, left, and Paetongtarn Shinawatra, in white, greeting supporters at the Bangkok airport last month.

item.title: Russia, Belarus and Iran Are Invited to 2023 Nobel Prize Ceremony
item.description: The executive director of the Nobel Foundation said it was reversing course from a year ago in an effort lower tensions at a time of growing geopolitical divisions.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova and Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: The 2022 Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony in Oslo, where antiwar efforts in Belarus, Russia and Ukraine were honored.

item.title: What to Know About the Deadly Johannesburg Fire
item.description: The blaze, one of the worst residential ones in South Africa’s history, occurred in a building that officials and locals say had become an overcrowded death trap for the hundreds who lived there.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Onlookers on Friday outside the five-story building that burned a day earlier in Johannesburg.

item.title: Identifying Victims in South African Fire Is a Grim Struggle
item.description: Families on Friday were trying to identify relatives caught in one of the deadliest residential fires in South African history, which health officials said would require DNA testing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Officers near the scene of the fire in Johannesburg on Friday. At least 74 people died, including a dozen children.

item.title: As Ukraine’s Fight Grinds On, Talk of Negotiations Becomes Nearly Taboo
item.description: Discussion of a Plan B, should Ukraine fail to win a total victory, has become more fraught than ever, say those who have tried.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Soldiers with the 110th Separate Mechanized Brigade after firing a DANA, a wheeled 152-millimeter self-propelled artillery gun, at a Russian target in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine on Aug. 26.

item.title: Europe’s ‘Tormented History’ Drives an Ambitious Macron Protégé
item.description: Clément Beaune, who had a double coming out as a gay man with Jewish roots, wants to be mayor of Paris, revive the center-left and build the united Europe he cherishes.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Clément Beaune, the French transportation minister, is eyeing a big political future. He is seen here in 2022, when he was secretary of state for European affairs.

item.title: Airline Sold Tickets for Already Canceled Flights, Watchdog Group Says
item.description: Australia’s consumer commission said in legal proceedings that Qantas, the country’s national carrier, had sold tickets for routes it never intended to fly.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Cleaning a Qantas aircraft in Sydney, Australia. The national carrier posted a record profit last month.

item.title: Textbooks for Russian High Schoolers Try to Justify Ukraine War
item.description: The textbooks, which cover Russian history from 1945 to present, also reimagine the brutality of Joseph Stalin’s policies.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: A portrait of President Vladimir V. Putin on a page of “Russia Today — The Special Military Operation,” a newly published textbook for Russian schools.

item.title: Promising unwavering support for Ukraine, the U.K. replaces its ex-soldier defense secretary with a savvy politician.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The newly appointed Defense Secretary Grant Shapps leaving No. 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Officials Have Visited China. Will Beijing Send Anyone?
item.description: Such visits could help convey Beijing’s interest in stabilizing ties with Washington. But China has been noncommittal.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Olivia Wang
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, with the foreign minister, Wang Yi, center, at the recent BRICS summit in Johannesburg.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The deaths of dozens of people in a fire in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Emergency vehicles and personnel surrounded the building in downtown Johannesburg.

item.title: Pope Visits Mongolia, With an Eye on Russia and China
item.description: The pontiff arrived Friday on a trip that the Vatican said was meant to encourage the fewer than 1,500 Catholics there. But it also brings him close to two great powers that have vexed him.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving at Chinggis Khaan International Airport in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, on Friday.

item.title: Could Australia and New Zealand Become One Nation?
item.description: A New Zealand lawmaker talked about the idea last week, though a union is unlikely ever to take place.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Australia flag was displayed before a Women’s World Cup soccer match in Sydney in July. Australia and New Zealand hosted the tournament.

item.title: With Robotyne Recaptured, Ukraine Takes Next Step in Counteroffensive
item.description: After penetrating Russian defenses to retake the village of Robotyne, Ukrainian forces have pushed the fight a few miles east, but formidable obstacles lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Constant Méheut and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier looking at a destroyed Ukrainian tank near the village of Robotyne last week.

item.title: Keith Spicer, Canada’s Offbeat Envoy of Reconciliation, Dies at 89
item.description: As the country’s first commissioner of official languages, he oversaw a dual-language mandate. He later led a task force to listen to Canadians’ complaints.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Fred Chartrand/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Canadian “Official Languages Commissioner” Keith Spicer speaks to reporters in 1975 about his efforts to promote a bilingual culture.

item.title: Gabon’s Leader, Ali Bongo Ondimba, Was More Admired Abroad Than at Home
item.description: Hailed as a climate visionary, Gabon’s president, Ali Bongo Ondimba, was once welcomed to Buckingham Palace but was blindsided by this week’s coup.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Dionne Searcey
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: President Ali Bongo Ondimba of Gabon and his French-born wife, Sylvia Bongo, in 2019, during celebrations marking the country’s independence from France in 1960.

item.title: Fire in Johannesburg, South Africa, Kills 74
item.description: Johannesburg, with a severe shortage of affordable housing, has hundreds of illegally occupied derelict buildings that officials and housing advocates say have become firetraps.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Outside the building in Johannesburg on Thursday. At least 12 children were among the victims.

item.title: Friday Briefing: A Deadly Fire in South Africa
item.description: Also, the U.S. resists engaging with the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: Lyna Bentahar
item.media:description: The authorities were still trying to determine the cause of the fire.

item.title: More Than 100 Schools in England Ordered to Close Buildings Over Faulty Concrete
item.description: The news came just days before the start of the academic year for most children, even though critics say the risks have been known for some time.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of students at a school in London in January.

item.title: Why the Johannesburg Apartment Building Was a Firetrap
item.description: A visit and imagery of the five-story building show that it had a litany of major safety issues that made it vulnerable to a deadly fire.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby, Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon

item.title: U.K. Names Grant Shapps as New Defense Minister
item.description: Ben Wallace, a former soldier, championed the Ukrainians in their war against Russia. His successor, Grant Shapps, is best known for his political skills.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The newly appointed Defense Secretary Grant Shapps leaving No. 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.

item.title: Humanity’s Ancestors Nearly Died Out, Genetic Study Suggests
item.description: The population crashed following climate change about 930,000 years ago, scientists concluded. Other experts aren’t convinced by the analysis.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Investigators Seize ‘Marcus Aurelius’ Statue From Cleveland Museum
item.description: The Manhattan district attorney’s office said the headless bronze, valued at $20 million, is a depiction of the Roman emperor and was looted from Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:description: The Cleveland Museum of Art acquired the bronze statue in 1986. The museum is now calling it “Draped Male Figure” on its website, but had earlier referred to it as a depiction of Marcus Aurelius.

item.title: VanMoof, Trendy E-Bike Brand, Bought Out of Bankruptcy by Scooter Maker
item.description: Lavoie, which makes high-end scooters based on McLaren’s Formula 1 technology, acquired the trendy e-bike brand that had gained a zealous following.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The WheelGood repair shop in Amsterdam is one of the few places where VanMoof owners could get their bikes repaired after the company declared bankruptcy.

item.title: Johannesburg Building Fire Photos: Scenes From a Deadly Blaze
item.description: The blaze struck an abandoned building that had become a crowded squatter settlement. The authorities were investigating the cause.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of a deadly blaze in downtown Johannesburg, South Africa, on Thursday.

item.title: UK Replaces Defense Secretary Ben Wallace With Grant Shapps
item.description: Mr. Wallace, a former soldier, had come to symbolize Britain’s steadfast support for Ukraine in the war against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Grant Shapps, who has been appointed as defense secretary, leaving Downing Street in London on Thursday.
